title: 103_hr3480
content: The Act is titled the "Apollo 11 Moon Landing 25th Anniversary Commemorative Coin Act". It specifies the coin specifications. The Secretary of the Treasury will issue up to 500,000 one dollar silver coins, each weighing 26.73 grams, with a diameter of 1.500 inches, and composed of 90% silver and 10% copper. The design of the coins will commemorate the 25th anniversary of the Moon landing, featuring inscriptions of "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The coins minted will be legal tender. The coins minted under this Act will be legal tender and considered numismatic items under title 31, United States Code. The Secretary will obtain silver for the coins from stockpiles. The design of each coin will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with the Commission of Fine Arts and reviewed by the Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee. The coins may be issued starting on July 20, 1994, and must cease minting by July 19, 1995. Only one mint facility will be used to strike the coins in different qualities. The Secretary will sell the coins at face value plus design and issuance costs. Bulk sales will have a discount, and prepaid orders will also receive a discount. A $10.00 surcharge will be added to all coin sales. Additionally, there is a general waiver of procurement regulations. SEC. 7. GENERAL WAIVER OF PROCUREMENT REGULATIONS. No procurement laws apply to goods and services for this Act, except for equal employment opportunity laws. SEC. 8. DISTRIBUTION OF SURCHARGES. Surcharges from coin sales go to Aerospace Education Alliance for math and science program. SEC. 9. AUDITS. The Comptroller General has the right to audit the Aerospace Education Alliance's financial records related to funds received under section 8. Financial assurances are also required. SEC. 10. FINANCIAL ASSURANCES. The Secretary must ensure minting coins won't cost the government. Payment for coins requires full payment, security, or a guarantee from a depository institution.
